ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Professor Smith provided a tremendous overview of statecraft through history with his syllabus. From Moses to Pericles to Machiavelli to Burke to Lincoln to Weber, we considered the idea of statesmanship as it has evolved throughout the years.
I didnt learn what a statesman was, but I did learn about the problems that arise for a statesman and how statesmen have adapted to changing historical contexts.
A framework for thinking about statesmanship, but primarily a chance to just speak on some of the most influential leaders in history.
It's a great political theory class on statesmanship

One major takeaway from this course is that it allowed me to explore fundamental questions (about political things and political leadership) in multiple, deeper ways. Rather than accepting an answer or two answer to a question, I learned to keep pushing on until every possible answer is exhausted. More importantly, I become a better writer  because of Professor Smith's invaluable feedback. I leave this course bolder and braver in my writing skill, and resolved in grappling with difficult, often uncomfortable questions, themes and ideas.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Truly, Professor Smith crafted a tremendous reading list. The essay assignments, too, were a great opportunity to dive deeply into a few of the thinkers we discussed in class. I do think the course would have benefited from some non-Western statecraft conceptions. For instance, statecraft in the Confucian tradition diverges profoundly from Western notions. Furthermore, I think we ought to have spent more time considering the context in which a particular statesman or notion of statecraft took place; the context in which Moses led was profoundly different than that in which Lenin led.

S - Loved the Bible weeks on Moses and David. It's what caught my attention to the class. 
W - Class was a little big, but it's such a good class I understand.
Wonderful Professor and topics covered on syllabus.
Everything about this course is perfect. I will only add that the class should try to generate more opposing views rather tread with a single view, perspective or interpretation.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely, Professor Smith is wonderful and I recommend all of his classes, especially his seminars.

One of the distributional requirements for the political science major should be a seminar with Professor Smith. His style of teaching and his approach to political philosophy changed the way I viewed the discipline. Furthermore, the course offered a broad approach to the study of statecraft, meaning the options for essays are incredibly flexible.
Yes, I recommend to a student looking to really learn from others in a seminarboth students and Smith.
Yes, moreso for the experience than the material. You will learn, but honestly it's just an enjoyable and interesting class, and Steven Smith is great,
Yes but only if you wanna learn about statesman

If you interested in politics and looking to explore the questions which lie at the core of political life, then this course is a perfect fate. In fact, I think this course should be taken by anyone interested in creating change in whatever field or area of study, because it explores leadership in all its various facets.
